title: 112_hr6723
content: The "Inspector General Improvement Act of 2012" is also known as the "Short Title". This Act assigns Inspector General to certain Federal entities. The Inspector General Improvement Act of 2012 assigns Inspector Generals to oversee audit and investigative activities in specific Federal entities, including the Agency for International Development and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Inspector General Improvement Act of 2012 assigns Inspector Generals to oversee audit and investigative activities in specific Federal entities, including the Financial Institutions Examination Council, Department of Defense (Selective Service System), and Department of Education (James Madison Memorial Fellowship Foundation, Christopher Columbus Fellowship Foundation). The Inspector General Improvement Act of 2012 designates Inspector Generals to supervise audit and investigative activities in various Federal entities, such as the Financial Institutions Examination Council, Department of Defense, and Department of Education. Additionally, specific duties are assigned to Inspector Generals in agencies like the Federal Labor Relations Authority and Department of Health and Human Services. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services supervises audit and investigative activities related to programs within specific entities like the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board, U.S. Interagency Council on Homelessness, and Medicare Payment Advisory Commission. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security has similar responsibilities for the Commission on the Prevention of Weapons of Mass Destruction Proliferation and Terrorism. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior supervises audit and investigative activities for various programs and operations, including the Arctic Research Commission, Office of the Federal Coordinator for Alaska Natural Gas Transportation, Valles Caldera Trust, and others. The Inspector General of the Department of Labor oversees audit and investigative activities for specific commissions and services, including the Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, and Federal Mediation Conciliation Service. The Inspector General of the Department of State also has duties specified in the Inspector General Act of 1978. The Inspector General of the Department of State supervises audit and investigative activities for programs within the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration oversees activities related to the United States Tax Court. The Inspector General of the Environmental Protection Agency supervises audit and investigative activities within the agency. The Inspector General of the General Services Administration supervises audit and investigative activities for programs within the National Capital Planning Commission, Commission of Fine Arts, and Committee for Purchase from People Who Are Blind or Severely Disabled. The Inspector General of the Government Accountability Office oversees activities related to audit and control within the office. The Inspector General of the Intelligence Community and the National Archives and Records Administration supervise audit and investigative activities related to programs and operations within their respective agencies. The Inspector General of various agencies supervises audit and investigative activities related to programs and operations within their respective agencies, including the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and Office of Personnel Management. The Inspector General of the Smithsonian Institution supervises audit and investigative activities related to programs and operations within the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.
